Replies.Reply: Jan Chapman Productions Pty Ltd 2 Fairlight Street Leichhart 2040 NSW Australia  4th draft 1991 Developed with the assistance of The Australian Film Commission   ----------------------------------------------------------------
Hold still you smutt! Blast the boat!
It's a little rough out there. Could be they can't get through to you in this weather. Maybe they'll come over land.
Have you things for shelter?
What things have you?
Does your mother prefer to come on with us to Nelson?
You be damn fortuned I don't smack your puppy gob, missy. Damn lucky.
She says, "thank you".
She says, No. She says she'd rather be boiled alive by natives than get back in your tub.
Mother... I'm thinking  ADA pauses.
I'm not going to call him Papa.  I'm not going to call HIM anything. I'm not even going to look at HIM.
It's my mother's piano.
It must come.
She wants it to come.
Mother wants to know if they could come back directly for it?
After they have taken the other things?
.... They met when my mother was an opera singer... in Luxemburg...
Why?
I want to be in the photograph.
In an enormous forest, with real fairies as bridesmaids each holding a little elf's hand.
Replies.Didascalie: (her Scottish accent becomes thick and expressive)

Replies.Reply: No, I tell a lie, it was in a small country church, near the mountains  AUNT MORAG is becoming involved again. She leans forward.
The Alps.
Mother used to sing the songs in German and her voice would echo across the valleys  That was before the accident....

One day when my mother and father were singing together in the forest, a great storm blew up out of nowhere. But so passionate was their singing that they did not notice, nor did they stop as the rain began to fall and when their voices rose for the final bars of the duet a great bolt of lightening came out of the sky and struck my father so that he lit up like a torch... And at the same moment my father was struck dead my mother was struck dumb! She- never-spoke-another-word.
Please take us to the beach where we landed.
Hello.
What on?
She says it's her piano, and she won't have him touch it. He's an oaf, he can't read, he's ignorant.
My mother wants to see your hands. Hold them out.
You have to wash them.
Wash them again.
There's no tune left in the piano so she can't teach you.
Mother says she can't stand to teach piano with it all out or tune. So I'm to do scales.
I hope you've scrubbed your hands.
What's out there?
You have to watch me where I put my fingers.
It's in tune.
I was teaching.
She wants to see what you can do.
Everyone has to practice.
What do you want to hear?
Tell me about my real father.
What happened? Why didn't you get married?
I want to speak to my mother  She buries her head in her mother's skirt.
Actually, to tell you the whole truth, Mama says most people speak rubbish and it's not worth the listen.
Yes, it's unholy.
The Holly and the Ivy...
I know why Mr. Baines can't play the piano.
She never gives him a turn.
Tomorrow.
He's given it to us.
What will I play?
Do I know any gigs?
Why? Why can't I?
I shan't practise and I DON'T CARE!
To HELL!
Stay still! It's the very worst knots.
Mama STOP IT!
Stop it I feel sick!
Mumma! Mumma! They are playing your piano!
Here Papa!
You shouldn't have gone up there, should you? I don't like it and nor does Papa. Mama, we can play cards together.
She is asleep, look.
Mama! Look out!

One, two, three One, two, three  ADA glances around at the bush. FLORA beams enjoying a feeling of familyness of which she is now the boss. The two women go ahead into the hut which STEWART shuts and secures with a beam.
STEWART reads, he glances at ADA who is glum and lifeless.
We're not supposed to visit him'.
The grand old Duke of York. He had ten thousand men etc.
Mumma wanted me to give this to Mr. Baines.
No, she says NOOOOOO!!!
Mother!!
Mama!
Mama.
He says you're not to see her or he'll chop her up!
I can't  BAINES rubs her back. FLORA straightens up.
She says, throw the piano overboard.
She doesn't want IT!
Are we stopping?... Do you want to stop?
Shall we stop?
Tai hoa! Me tatari tatou .., me tutatou I konei.
She looks tired.
Anei nga pouaka - ko era e toro.
something?
aha tenei?
Someone died here. It's tapu.
No, no they know another track - to the side of this.
I'm not able to read.
I don't have the time.
Replies.Didascalie: (FLORA and ADA stare evenly at him)

Replies.Reply: I - can't - take - you there. I can't do it.
Those 80 acres, that cross the stream, what do you think of them?
I'd like to make a swap.
The piano.
No.
Yes, I thought that.
I'll have to get lessons. It wouldn't be much use without them.
They are washed.
The marks do not come out. They are scars and hardened skin.
I can't play.
No, I can't.
I'd rather not play. I want to listen and learn that way.
I just want to listen.
Anything.
Do you know how to bargain, nod if you do.
You see I'd like us to make a deal. There's things I want to do while you stay. If you let me you can earn it back.
Your dress?
Play... Keep playing.
No, no bible readers.
I have a wife.
She lives her own life in New Jersey, America.
Lift your skirt,  ADA stops playing. She turns to him. Thinks about it then slowly lifts her skirt a little to show her boots.
Higher.
I want to see your arms.
Play.
Ada, four keys.
I can't read music, I have just begun.
I have been waiting. You are very late.
I don't want you to play. I just want you to sit.
No, not two keys.
Two keys then!
Te, kawnarna paraikete mo te tahi hawlie 0 te whenna uci.
Yes, why not.
Do what you like. Play what you like.
I want to lie together without clothes on. How many would that be?
Yes, ten keys.
I am giving the piano back to you. I've had enough.  The arrangement is making you a whore and me wretched.
It's yours, leave, go on go!
I don't want to learn.
No.
No, no payment. I have given it back. I don't want it.
It was more to your wife that I gave it.
So what brings you here? Did you leave something? I have not found anything.

Ada, I am unhappy because I want you, because my mind has seized on you and thinks of nothing else. This is how I suffer, I am sick with longing. I don't eat, I don't sleep. If you do not want me, if you have come with no feeling for me, then go!
What?  What?  whisper....
what will you do? Will you come again?
miss you. Ada, do you love me?
Come tomorrow. If you are serious, come tomorrow.
Tomorrow?
Homni 'ci au.
He aha to hiahia? Ask for it? Tobacco?
I'll be back.
Can you read?
Can you read?
Say it again, just you.
What has happened? Hush, hush, what is it?
What happened?
Quiet down! Shhh! Where is she?
Jesus! I'll kill him! I'll kill him.
You mean in signs?
No, not words.
Spoken words?
What are they?
You punished her wrongly, it was me, my fault.
No, I love her, we will be a family. I have her piano. I will mend it, she will get better.
No, she needs it, she must have it.
What did she say?
It's quite safe, they are managing...
What?
I have the key here, look, I'll have it mended...
Please, Ada, you will regret it. It's your piano, I want you to have it.
All right. sit down, sit down.

STEWART takes out a comb and drags it dazed and zombie like through his wet hair. Inside the darkness of his pocket, he turns over and over a small, worn edged photograph, a smudge of green light allows us to see ADA's tumbling face. Taking it in the heel of his hand he secretly looks at it. Just as the party return and settle he stares on ahead possessed and determined.
A man points at FLORA's feet and gestures as if holding one of the little shoes in his hand.
FLORA is struck by shyness and hides under her mother's skirt. ADA cannot look straight at STEWART and STEWART also cannot look at her.
STEWART nods suspiciously towards the MAORI speaker not understanding him, the speaker smiles and nods back.
E Nilie, E Nihe he Kohuru, he kohurn?
NIHE waves them down, but they are shaken up and only crouch above their seats. The others stare anxiously between NIHE and the stage.
BLUEBEARD moves closer, the young wife drops to her knees her hands held up in prayer.

Only NIHE and his top-hatted daughter remain calmly in their seats. The warriors have BLUEBEARD cornered and whimpering an umbrella held spear-like above him. NIHE stomps his stick, his great voice booming out.
He messes up the pattern of twigs as he speaks.
The MAORI NEGOTIATOR gets up to leave as do the others, STEWART snatches back his blankets and sulkily shakes them out to fold.
We must get on.
Miss McGrath, Alisdair Stewart. You'll have to wake yourself. I've got men here to carry your things.
I see you have a good many boxes, I'd like to know what is in each.
CAN - YOU - HEAR - ME?
Well that is good, yes that is good, good.
What's in here?
Ohh, yes so it is, written there, crockery.
And this one?
You're small. I never thought you'd be small.
What's here?
What's in here then, lead?
A piano?
Tell them to carry in pairs.  Those three and those two the black and the red, then the suitcases.
What do you think?
She's stunted, that's one thing.
Oh no, it can't come now.
Do you mean you don't want your kitchenware or your clothes? Is that what you mean?
Let us not discuss this further. I am very pleased....
I suggest you prepare for a difficult journey. The bush will tear clothes and the mud is deep in places.
What are they doing? We don't have time for that.
What's he say?
But we came down this way didn't we? I'm sure we did.
They want more money. They are trying to make two days out of it?
Beautiful.
I am hoping you will use the time to settle in, and, in some ways we may start again  FLORA and ADA look at each other.
All right?
Hello, then.
What would you think if someone played a kitchen table like it were a piano?
It's strange isn't it? I mean it's not a piano, it doesn't make any sound.
I knew she was mute, but now I'm thinking it's more than that. I'm wondering if she's not brain affected.
No, it was a table.
Well it has not yet come to anything. Just a concern.
And with time she will, I'm sure, become affectionate.
On your property?
Good, flatish land with reliable water, why? I don't have money. What are you about?
What for?
The piano on the beach? Ada's piano?
It's not marshy is it?
You'd have to organise it up here.
Well Baines the music lover, I never would have known. Hidden talents George.
Yes, I suppose you would.
Well Ada can play.
I have got us some excellent land. Baines has taken some queer idea to have a piano, and you are to give him lessons. Have you taught before?
On your piano, that is the swap.
What does she say?
He wants to improve himself...
You can't go on like this, we are a family now, all of us make sacrifices and so will you.
I'd try children's tunes, nothing more complicated  ADA is unrepentant, she does not want to teach BAINES the piano.
Just be encouraging no one expects him to be good.
It looks good, very nice looking thing. Well . I wish you luck. The girls are very excited about the lessons.
Flora will explain anything Ada says.
Shall I kiss you goodnight?
Wait.
How are the lessons going?
Lot of fools. Come on, move up.
What do they say? Are they selling? Offer the blankets for half the land.
Replies.Didascalie: (muttering to BAINES across the previous speech)

Replies.Reply: Offer the guns.
What do they want it for? They don't cultivate it, burn it back, anything. How do they even know it's theirs?
Ada says you're doing well with the piano?
I'll have to come and hear you play. what do you play.
No. Well I suppose it takes time.
Baines can't play a damn thing. Is that right he can't play a thing?
What's that?
The MAORI WOMEN keep up an unacknowledged chant.
You've missed this bit.
And when is the next lesson?
Stop right there'. This isn't yours  what are you doing with the piano?
Hah, you're very cunning Ada, but I've seen through you, I'm not going to lose the land this way. Wait here!
I don't think you should have given up the piano. I will make sure you are properly taught, with music written on to sheets and...
You don't want to learn.
And what does this do to our bargain? I cannot afford the piano if you mean me to pay.
Well, I doubt I want it very much myself.
Well, thank you, I expect she will appreciate it.
Is it all right? Aren't you going to play something?
Play a gig.

Play a song then  FLORA starts a song, ADA walks past them out of the hut, STEWART ignores her exit moving up to lean on the piano. ADA is seen through the hut window wandering amidst the ghostly, blackened trunks. STEWART'S attention is drawn to ADA, he interrupts FLORA'S singing with a sudden outburst.
Why won't she play it? We have it back, and she just wanders off!
Keep playing!
Where's your mother? Where has she gone?
You are letting the clothes float off... They are floating off.
Ada!
Baines is packing up?
If you leave soon, yes, I am sure of it.
I've been hoping you would come.
I want to touch you Why can't I touch you? Do you like me?
We must both get on. I have decided to trust you to stay here. You will not see Baines?
Good, good. Perhaps with more trying you will come to like me?
No!!
why? WHY? I trusted you!
Do you love him? Do you?! Is it him you love?
Take this to Baines. Tell him if he ever tries to see her again I'll take off another and another and another!
I lost my temper. I'm sorry.

You cannot send love to HIM you cannot do it.  Even to think on it makes me angry, very angry  ADA opens her eyes and looks at STEWART. It is evident she hears nothing and has understood nothing, she is struggling with pain. Her face grimaces and she groans.
I meant to love you. I clipped your wing, that is all.
We shall be together, you will see it will be better...

Ohhhhh my love  His hand begins to move further and further up her leg, nudging the nightgown higher and higher. He looks at her face. She is closed-eyed, unconscious. STEWART'S face crinkles into a pained expression and all his control melts into a drive to hold and extend this moment. He brings his mouth to her leg and begins to kiss her knee, her thigh. A new thought occurs to him, a terrible thought, but as he has phrased the thought to himself, he cannot resist it. He glances at her face still fevered and unconscious. Quietly, stealthily, he begins to undo his belt buckle. He bends across her to gently separate her legs. As he moves his body over her, he looks towards her and to his shame and horror she is looking directly back at him, her eyes perfectly on his, perfectly focused. Quietly STEWART moves back and pulls down her gown, all the time keeping his eyes on her.
You are feeling better?
What...?
Put that away, on the floor.

I look at you, at your face. I have had that face in my head hating it. But now I am here seeing it ... it's nothing, you blink, you have your mark, you look at me through your eyes, yes. you are even scared of me  STEWART laughs.
Look at you!
Has Ada ever spoken to you?
No, words. You have never heard words?
Never thought you heard words?
my head. I watched her lips, they did not make the words, yet the harder I listened the clearer I heard her, as clear as I hear you, as dear as I hear my own voice.
that it's a trick, that I'm making it up. No, the words I heard, were her words.
She said, "I have to go, let me go, let Baines take me away, let him try and save me. I am frightened of my will, of what it might do it is so strange and strong".

Understand me. I am here for her, for her I wonder that I don't wake, that I am not asleep to be here talking with you. I love her. But what is the use? She doesn't care for me. I wish her gone. I wish you gone. I want to wake and find it was a dream, that is what I want. I want to believe I am not this man. I want my self back; the one I know.
Aue tepatupsiarehe!
STEWART struggles up to the front to join BAINES, he speaks over the top of HONE.
STEWART continues over the top of the MAORI discussion.
Tern - tern!
The MAORIS look carefully at the quality of the blankets, noting the depth of the weave and the strength of the Wool. They shake their heads as they discuss them.
Kahore ne huarahi - kahorene tutae.

E Hoal  HONE takes an aggressive fighting posture towards BAINES, insulted that BAINES should suggest he might carry anything. HONE does not carrying, he is the boss. With great dignity HONE retreats, too injured to help. Other MAORIS come up and BAINES assigns them boxes. ADA gets worried, the piano is being left alone. She writes on her pad, "THE PIANO?" She shows STEWART.
E hinga te Koroua ra B Pitama i konci. Kare noa Kia hikina te tapu.
E Tarna heke atu ki ram - tiro his atu.
Watch your feet!
Careful! Watch his hand.
Stop it!
We'll bring out the bride.
LIFT - YOUR - ARM - UP - DEAR.
Ohh the tag is broken.
I thought she met your father in Luxemburg.
And where did they get married?
Which mountains are those dear?
Oh what happened?
Ohhh ... dear. Not another word From the shock, yes it would be.

Terrible.  Terrible  Before she can undo the ties ADA pulls it from herself so aggressively that the ties and part of the gown comes apart. None of this is a concern to ADA who is distracted with fear for her piano. She crosses to the little window and stares anxiously at the falling rain.
You see these are the slits that the heads will go through, show him Nessie ...
Replies.Didascalie: (without pause but referring to the sheet)

Replies.Reply: Like it were a piano?
Biscuits.' No, no sound.
No sound at all?
Oh, yes, yes of course, a concern.
Oh indeed. Cotton'.
Certainly, there is nothing so easy to like as a pet and they are quite silent.
Which sign is the word rehearsal?
I can't imagine a fate worse than being dumb. Turn around.
Well, that is a strong opinion.
I hardly need to give one to you, but there you are anyway.
That is good, yes.
Mr. Baines, do come and turn pages  BAINES looks wildly about for rescue.
Ohhh, it's so dark, it's like a dank cave.
Ohh no, it makes my skin creep!
Alisdair, is it because of our play? Have the natives aggressed you?

We have just come from George Banes' and they have taken him over. It is no wonder he is leaving, he has got in too deep with the natives. They sit on his floor as proud as Kings, but without a shred of manners.
He is quite altered, as if they had been trying some native witchcraft on him. Well tomorrow or the day after he will be gone.

Well he has NOTHING to pack, but he is leaving. And it is just as well; Nessie has foolishly grown an affection for him ... we have had some tears  At this mention NESSlE's face crumples and tears again begin to flow.
STOP IT! STOP!  NESSIE remarkably obeys, blinking her face back to shape.
You know I am thinking of the piano. She does not play the piano as we do Nessie.
Watch your feet!
It will be very dramatic.
and wiped her feet an it.
To be deaf?
Oh, no use Mr Stewart, I can't act.
Yes, like a cave.
... you are quite trapped.
... without a shred of manners.
Ohhhhhh!
A pid-geon Auntie.
You don't play?
Well my dear Miss Broadbent, tuned, but silent.
I got the good wife for you Peini. She pray good. Clean. Read Bible. You sleep her Peini. She chief daughter.
Why? We need you pakeha clever. You sleep her.
Don't answer, he low born. Jun look at him, mongrel. Your wife where she?
You have spare wife here Peini. You get rnana for that. Our chief four wives.
Who do that? It not finish, that no good Peini. You finish!
George, can I use this comb?
George sick, he don't wanna see nobody. You got Tupeka for the Hira?
You make BIG mistake George. In first place you should swap land for wife. Now look, she gone, you no land, no music box, you got nothing.
I worry for us Peini. Pakeha cunning like wind, KNOCK you over, yet you not see it. Some they say, how can pakeha get our land if we won't sell it?"
They wrong Peini. We need guns to hold it.
I worried Feini. What's gonna happen you, you go home, but where we go? We got nowhere to go.
Gun, ask for his gun!
Go Peini ... Haere atu e Peini.
Peini, Peini, liddle gel. I seen her come up here, scream, scream . blood on her. Look bad... very bad  BAINES jumps off his horse and strides into his hut.
Put her down Peirn She is liddle.
I worry for you.
I miss you.
He rimu teretere koc ete. Peini eeeii, Tere 'Ci Tawhiti 'ci Paniamao eeeii He waka Teretere He waka teretere.
I give her clever eb Peini. Hallelujah!
Nessie, your hand out ... out here, please.
Nessie, please.
Look you are being attacked!
And so the young maid came upon each and all of Bluebeard's missing wives, their severed heads still bleeding, their eyes still crying.
A loud improvised door slam and heavy footsteps. NESSIE, in costume, freezes. The shadow of Bluebeard moves clumsily down the cut-out banister and along the corridor.
Replies.Didascalie: (AUNT MORAG looks around gasping, fooled despite herself)

Replies.Reply: They're bringing in extra seats!
Oh God, don't pin my hair too high Alfred!
Two of the women are putting a little c4ouring on each of the angels while two other angels are being smacked for putting their white gloved hands in the bucket of blood.
Look who's here, the musical MR BAINES What will we have tonight George, "Twinkle, twinkle?"
'Mary had a little lamb' or a polka, come on George what's it to be?
I am home early my sweet wife ... where art thou?
Yes wife, a surprise indeed! So now you know my secret you, the sweetest and youngest or all my wives must be prepared to die.
I shall not wait. Bare your neck.
Hello husband, what a surprise!
No, no wait!
E te whsnau keite pai-he takaro tenei.
Hoki rnai! Hoki rnai!
Ac ra. Kia Ora! Kia Ora! Te Peini.
He aha te pononga 0 te whenus pena kahore he Pu hei pupuri?
What o'clock say Mr Stewart?
It is mine. I found it.
I can.
Yes ... lots of things.
I can read!
She can't read, she's my sister, I ought to know.
She can't.
She can't read.
Running writing, we haven't done that yet.
That's "My".
Yes it is.
It doesn't make sense.
Dear George you have my heart, Ada McGrath.
Myrtle can read it, her mother taught her.
D e a r  G e o r g e  The children look over at BAINES to see if this is right so far.
McGrath.
That's all  They all look up at him.
Dear George you have my heart, Ada McGrath.
Leave it - its too heavy.
Ae! Peja. Turakina'. Bushit? Peja te kawheha kite moana.
He patene te kai, he patene te kai A popo ka tiko patene ahan patene ma nga tangata katoa.
